job_title: Executive Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: I'm sure employment experiences vary greatly depending on what department you're in, but in my department all of my colleagues were top-notch, and the benefit options were generous. The university structure meant quick responses to any HR or administrative questions.
cons: Also probably varies greatly by department, but mine was subject to micromanaging.

job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Phila, PA
pros: Highly talented faculties. Students are incredible to work with.
cons: Little or no opportunity to receive raises and promotions.

review_title: Great coworkers, Little to no room for growth
pros: Coworkers are excellent. Faculty is extremely talented. Staff Council + Faculty Council advocate well. Downtown location is easy to commute to. Tuition remission benefits are well worth taking advantage of.
cons: They have not raised salary for cost of living in many years. I have received a huge increase in scope and responsibility but not in pay. Burnout is high. Good temporary position and can turn into a career institution for some, but not most.

pros: Staff, Faculty, and Students are incredible to work with
cons: Staff has little to no opportunity to receive raises or promotions. No seat at the decision-making table. Constant turnover. HR does not work for the community, but instead protects the school.

review_title: Ok but no room to move up
pros: Loved my coworkers and students
cons: Very political environment and no places to move up or to learn from experience

pros: Art and great students! Health care was ok

pros: PTO, medical benefits, retirement plan, collaborative & fun community

job_title: Live Sound Tech in Philadelphia, PA

review_title: Nice coworkers and students, low pay, exploitative business model.
pros: Coworkers are great, despite bad pay and little chance for raises and promotions. Great location, lots of time off, chance to work with young artists.
cons: Pay is low, even for a small art school. Finances have been mismanaged for years at the highest levels. Admissions and Financial Aid are under enormous pressure to enroll any and all students, preferably high-income, to keep the money flowing. But high-income students are hard to come by, so UArts makes up the difference by bringing in low-income students and having them take on tons and tons of debt. The Office of Financial Aid should be renamed The Office of Crushing Loans. It's not unusual for a student to graduate with over 100k of high interest debt. Meanwhile, most courses are taught by adjuncts earning starvation wages. If you can't pay you teachers and have to cripple your students financially to keep the doors open (and your pockets fat), then you're not training artists, you're exploiting them.

review_title: Great place to work, in spite of some dysfunction
pros: Great people: faculty, staff & students. Opportunities to see performances, art exhibitions and other events showcasing the talented student body. Generous benefit day package. Located in the heart of the city.
cons: Salaries are lower than industry standards. Many departments are understaffed and underfunded. Some internal dysfunction related to communication between departments and with the entire campus community, as well as some processes that need to be evaluated and improved. No opportunity to earn merit increases and some years not even a small cost-of-living increase.

pros: Many of the staff members were also artists, there is a great creative community that truly cares about the students.
cons: Pay is well below average, I left my position taking a lower position and title and still was making more. They cut some retirement matching. They were fairly transparent about lower revenues (fewer students) but constantly found a different person or department to blame, then overhauled the curriculum and speculated on buildings and new programs. They were letting anyone in and retention went down since many students were not ready for college, this while putting enormous pressure on admissions and financial aid.

review_title: Great People and Environment- Low pay with not much room for growth
pros: Great location in Center City, Philadelphia. Passionate and creative coworkers. The health benefits are actually pretty great compared to other institutions.
cons: The pay is very low, and they haven't adjusted salaries to reflect the increase in cost of living in many years. This is often a topic of discussion at town hall meetings, but it just isn't happening. Many excellent talent gets lost because of this which is a shame. I likely will have to find new employment because of this. There also isn't much room to grow or seek promotion.

pros: Talented and dedicated faculty and staff who are willing to go above and beyond, tons of vacation time, students are truly unique and special
cons: Questionable HR practices, low salaries, no staff professional development, no compensation to faculty and staff for overtime worked, discriminatory promoting practices - older white men with limited education and no management skills are most likely to be promoted, leadership is extremely out of touch with needs of young creative people, students of color, and LBGTQ community, although many on staff and faculty tirelessly advocate for these communities

pros: Academic staff are very approachable and very professional.Extremely helpful and always accessible,friendly and kind.working hours were good with overtime during the holiday periods when students were away.
cons: One or two of the facilities staff were lazy,bone idle and arrogant.Lateness and going home early when management were not around.Like to spend as much time as possible surfing the net and going shopping.No chance of promotion or progression.

pros:
-Supportive staff
-Great Dean (in Liberal Arts)
-Creative students
-Small classes
-Autonomy in teaching
-Good work conditions (supplies, office, etc)
cons:
-Terrible pay
-No benefits
-Many students unprepared for a college environment
-Some colleagues uninterested in improving teaching
-No budget for improving rigor of curriculum

review_title: Theatre Technician In Work Study Program
job_title: Theatre Technician Work Study in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Generally fun atmosphere. Feels professionally paced. Large amount of on the job learning experiences. Good place to do some networking. Ability to work rentals for larger hourly salary. Very flexible schedules.
cons: Hours are limited and competed for. Pay is minimum wage most of the time. Rentals are given to the same couple of people. Supervisors tend to bicker amongst themselves over calendars and sometimes blame students for their mistakes.

job_title: Assistant to the Director in Philadelphia, PA
pros: A community of artists and educators makes for a potentially very fulfilling work environment.
cons: The lack of support from leadership and mismanagement of finances stifles creativity and prevents employees from having a healthy work / life balance.

pros: The location is great, the students are talented and hard working, and my colleagues are top notch in the field
cons: Too many silos, lack of leadership. That should change soon though with a new president

review_title: Moving in Right Direction But Hindered By COVID Economy
pros:
* Leadership has progressive ideas
* Faculty and staff genuinely care about the students
* Great creative environment
* Generous 401k match
cons: * Very dependent on tuition, so annual enrollment determines how much can be done to improve programs, facilities, and other areas.

pros: The students, the faculty, the staff
cons: Severely understaffed and underfunded. Highly qualified people are overlooked.
